awd_titl_txt: RET Site: Research Experiences for Teachers in Biologically-inspired Computing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site at the University of South Alabama.  In-service middle school and high school teachers from Mobile and Baldwin County Public Schools will spend six weeks each summer engaged with research activities focused on biologically-inspired computing. The RET teachers will be guided by an interdisciplinary group of  faculty from the University of South Alabama as well as industry partners on discovery-based research projects in the area of neuromorphic systems, biologically-inspired systems to support machine learning applications.  The RET teachers will design standards-compliant curriculum modules which they will implement in their classrooms during the academic year and conduct workshops for other teachers.  The teachers will also participate in many professional development activities during the summer research activity and the academic year. This project should develop a lasting relationship between the university, the K-12 schools, and the surrounding community that can help to build a strong educational foundation in the schools supported by the university and the other partners.

The RET site is anchored by a compelling computing and engineering research area, neuromorphic systems.  The research projects span applications, architecture, circuits, and devices that enable future computing systems.  The projects build on the expertise and on-going research of the faculty mentors.  The technical areas to be investigated include novel imagery collection techniques and image processing algorithms for cancer detection, spiking neural network algorithms for imagery data, new power-efficient memory architecture and circuits to support the algorithms that are developed, and new memristor device-based neuromorphic system design for better prediction and accuracy. The research will provide teachers around for developing creative course modules in mathematics, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and technology that align well with state and national curriculum standards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this RET project was to establish a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) site at the University of South Alabama and to offer a research-intensive program in biologically-inspired computing systems for middle and high-school STEM teachers. In this three-year RET program, eight teachers participated in Year 1, twelve in Year 2, and seventeen in Year 3. The participating teachers came from sixteen schools in the Mobile County and eight schools in the Baldwin County. The school subjects they taught include Mathematics, Chemistry and Science, Engineering, Physics, Biology, Earth Science, and Robotics. Through the classroom implementations, over eight hundred and forty students were directly impacted. Two regional workshops were organized to disseminate the results of this program.

Intellectual Merit

The research team and participating teachers have developed new AI algorithms and bio-inspired computing system design techniques to support the target application– cancer detection. They also conducted educational research to advance the field. The RET participating teachers have actively conducted research with the team. So far, this project has yield 16 peer-reviewed journal and conference publications.

From the educational research perspective, the team used a design-based research approach to improve the quality of the RET project. For example, in the 2021 summer program, teachers were assigned to work on different research projects from the beginning. In the 2022 summer program, teachers learned foundational AI algorithm and hardware knowledge together before they were divided and spent weeks on a specific AI research project. Results of the comparison studies found two major benefits of the 2022 program design, including (i) a statistically significant increase in teachers’ technological content knowledge in AI and (ii) an increase of teaching AI concepts in teachers’ lessons. This work received Thomas C. Evans Engineering Education Paper Award, Southeast Section of ASEE (2024).

From the AI research perspective, the team has developed a new AI framework to perform real-time hyperspectral imaging based cancer classification and visualization with different speed/classification performance trade-offs by tailoring the dimensionality of the dataset, supporting different dimensions of deep learning models, and varying the architecture of models. This work was published in the Scientific Reports – Nature. Also, several different memristor-based bio-inspired system design techniques have been developed, which were published in leading journals and conferences, such as IEEE Journal on Emerging and Selected Topics in Circuits and Systems, IEEE Internet of Things Journal, and IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices.

Broader Impact

The boarder impacts of this project can be highlighted as follows.

In addition to the RET participants, this project also trained four graduate students including three instructional design graduate students and one PhD student in Engineering.

The team collaborated with the University of South Alabama Research and In-Service Center (SARIC) and submitted application for Teacher Excellence and Accountability for Mathematics and Science (TEAMS) teacher PD to Alabama State Department of Education, which was approved in 2023.

Six RET teachers co-led two regional workshops and shared their experiences in integrated AI education. One workshop took place at the Alabama Educational Technology Conference 2024 and the other one at the South Alabama Research and In-Service Center (SARIC). The workshop participants provided very positive feedback in the post-workshop surveys.
